intro: Ipomopsis tenuituba subsp. macrosiphon, commonly known as the narrowleaf ipomopsis, is a perennial flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and showy, tubular flowers that range in color from blue to purple. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and nutrient-poor conditions. Its narrow, linear leaves and elongated flower buds are key botanical features that distinguish it from other species in the genus. The subspecies macrosiphon is notable for its larger corolla tube compared to other subspecies within the species.
